title: LVAD and ICP Management
sbar:
0600: RN Sarah Jones reporting on Mr. Robert Miller, a 68-year-old male (DOB 03/15/1958) admitted yesterday at 2300 for increased intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to a fall. He has a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and a HeartMate II LVAD implanted 3 years ago. 

0605: Neuro assessment reveals GCS of 11 (E3, V3, M5), pupils are equal and sluggishly reactive. Right-sided weakness is noted. ICP is trending upwards, currently at 22 mmHg. MAP is 95 mmHg. LVAD parameters: flow 5.2 L/min, speed 9000 RPM, PI 6.0. Patient is on continuous EEG monitoring. 

0610: Current orders include mannitol 25g IV q4h, continuous hypertonic saline infusion at 30 mL/hr, and strict head-of-bed elevation to 30 degrees. Recent CT scan shows mild cerebral edema. 

0615: I'm concerned about the rising ICP despite current interventions. I recommend consulting neurosurgery for possible further intervention, such as external ventricular drain (EVD) placement. Also, please evaluate the LVAD parameters in the context of increased afterload from the elevated ICP. Consider optimizing MAP to maintain CPP between 60-70 mmHg. I will continue close monitoring of neuro status, ICP, and LVAD function.

physical_exam.Neuro: GCS 11 (E3, V3, M5). Pupils equal, sluggishly reactive. Right-sided weakness noted.
physical_exam.Cardio: LVAD hum audible. No murmurs. Peripheral pulses 2+ bilaterally.
physical_exam.Resp: Breath sounds clear bilaterally. No adventitious sounds.
physical_exam.Skin: Warm, dry, intact. No edema noted.

radiology.CT_Head: Mild cerebral edema. No acute hemorrhage or mass effect.

care_plan.Goal: Maintain ICP < 20 mmHg and CPP between 60-70 mmHg
Interventions: Elevate head of bed to 30 degrees.
Administer mannitol 25g IV q4h as ordered.
Administer continuous hypertonic saline infusion at 30 mL/hr as ordered.

question: Based on the provided information, which of the following interventions are MOST appropriate for this patient?

options.text: Administer a bolus of normal saline to increase preload and LVAD flow.
options.rationale: Administering a bolus of normal saline may worsen cerebral edema and increase ICP. The focus should be on managing ICP, not necessarily increasing LVAD flow at the expense of neurological status. While LVAD preload is important, it is secondary to managing the life-threatening ICP elevation.

options.text: Increase the rate of hypertonic saline infusion to reduce cerebral edema.
options.rationale: Hypertonic saline helps to draw fluid out of the brain tissue, reducing cerebral edema and subsequently lowering ICP. Increasing the infusion rate (within safe limits and as per physician orders) can be an appropriate intervention to manage rising ICP. The sodium level should be closely monitored to avoid hypernatremia.

options.text: Lower the head of the bed to improve cerebral perfusion.
options.rationale: Lowering the head of the bed will increase ICP by increasing cerebral blood volume. Head-of-bed elevation is a standard intervention to promote venous drainage and reduce ICP. This would directly contradict the established care plan for managing elevated ICP.

options.text: Administer a dose of furosemide to reduce fluid volume.
options.rationale: While furosemide can reduce fluid volume, it can also decrease intravascular volume, potentially reducing preload to the LVAD and compromising its function. Furthermore, rapid fluid shifts can worsen cerebral edema. Hypertonic saline is preferred for ICP management in this scenario. Furosemide also has a slower onset than hypertonic saline.

options.text: Contact neurosurgery for consideration of external ventricular drain (EVD) placement.
options.rationale: Given the rising ICP despite current medical management, consulting neurosurgery for EVD placement is appropriate. An EVD can directly drain cerebrospinal fluid, rapidly reducing ICP. This is a crucial step when conservative measures are insufficient. The SBAR also mentions this as a recommendation, indicating the urgency of this action.

options.text: Increase the LVAD speed to improve cardiac output.
options.rationale: Increasing the LVAD speed may increase cardiac output, but it may also increase afterload and potentially worsen ICP. The focus should be on optimizing MAP and CPP while primarily addressing the neurological issue. The LVAD parameters should be adjusted in collaboration with a specialist and in the context of the patient's overall condition, prioritizing ICP management.

clinicalPearls: In patients with LVADs and neurological compromise, prioritize ICP management while carefully monitoring LVAD parameters. Hypertonic saline is often preferred over diuretics for cerebral edema. Maintaining adequate cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is crucial, but avoid interventions that could significantly compromise LVAD function. Early neurosurgical consultation is key for refractory ICP elevation.
questionTrap: Many students may focus solely on the LVAD parameters and overlook the critical need to manage the elevated ICP. Be sure to prioritize interventions that directly address the neurological emergency while considering the impact on cardiac function.
mnemonic: I-C-P: Intervene, Consult, Prioritize (ICP management). L-V-A-D: Look, Verify, Adjust, Document (LVAD parameters).
references: Kirkpatrick, P. J., Smielewski, P., Czosnyka, M., & Menon, D. K. (2008). Intracranial pressure monitoring in head injury. British Journal of Anaesthesia, 101(1), 65-76.
Rogers, J. G., et al. (2017). HeartMate II left ventricular assist device for bridge-to-transplantation: A comprehensive review. Journal of the American College of Cardiology, 69(7), 855-876.
Le Roux, P. D., et al. (2014). Guidelines for management of severe traumatic brain injury, 4th edition. Neurosurgery, 75(Suppl 1), S1-S94.
